verses.text: For this reason, I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus for the sake of you Gentiles—
verses.comment: Paul introduces himself as a prisoner, emphasizing his suffering for the Gentiles. Paul’s role in bringing the gospel to non-Jews is central to this letter. His suffering mirrors Christ’s redemptive suffering (cf. Col 1:24).

verses.text: Assuming you have heard about the stewardship of God’s grace that was given to me for you,
verses.comment: Stewardship here points to a ministerial office entrusted by God. Paul is a chosen servant administering God's grace, showing a clear New Testament pattern of God working through human leadership to dispense his gifts (see also Acts 9:15).

verses.text: that was made known to me by revelation, as I have already written briefly.
verses.comment: Paul’s knowledge of the gospel is not from men, but comes directly from divine revelation. Compare to Galatians 1:12, where Paul insists his teaching is from Christ himself.

verses.text: By reading this, you can understand my insight into the mystery of Christ,
verses.comment: ‘Mystery’ here, as in Colossians 1:27, refers to divine truths once hidden but now revealed in Christ. Paul’s writing passes on this insight to the church.

verses.text: which in other generations was not made known to mankind as it has now been revealed to his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit:
verses.comment: The Spirit reveals the full truth to apostles and prophets, showing the Spirit works through the leadership of the Church to guide it into all truth (cf. John 16:13).

verses.text: that the Gentiles are fellow heirs, members of the same body, and partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus through the gospel.
verses.comment: Gentiles are not second-class citizens but full members of God’s people. This unity in one body is both visible and spiritual, fulfilled especially in the gathered assembly and its sacraments (see 1 Cor. 12:13).

verses.text: Of this gospel I became a servant according to the gift of God’s grace, which was given to me by the working of his power.
verses.comment: Paul’s apostolic service is grounded in grace and divine power, not his own ability. This points to how God empowers those whom He calls.

verses.text: To me, though I am the least of all the saints, this grace was given, to proclaim to the Gentiles the unfathomable riches of Christ,
verses.comment: Paul humbly recognizes himself as the least, showing that ministry is a gift, not a personal achievement. The ‘riches of Christ’ speaks to the boundless spiritual blessings believers receive in Him.

verses.text: and to bring to light for everyone the plan of the mystery hidden for ages in God, who created all things,
verses.comment: Paul stresses both the universality of God as Creator and the unfolding of his mysterious plan through history. God’s hidden plan finds its center in Christ and his Church.

verses.text: so that through the church the manifold wisdom of God might now be made known to the rulers and authorities in the heavenly places.
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is displayed through the visible church to even the spiritual beings, underscoring the unique role of the Church in God’s divine plan (see Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: This was according to the eternal purpose that he accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord,
verses.comment: All is according to God’s eternal plan, accomplished in Jesus. His work is finished, and believers are called to enter and participate in that accomplishment through Christ.

verses.text: in whom we have boldness and access with confidence through faith in him.
verses.comment: Christ grants direct access to God with confidence—a privilege realized in communal prayer and worship (see Heb. 10:19-22).

verses.text: Therefore I ask you not to lose heart over my sufferings for you, which are your glory.
verses.comment: Paul’s suffering benefits the church. The idea of suffering for others’ spiritual benefit echoes the participation of believers in Christ’s sufferings (Col. 1:24).

verses.text: For this reason I bow my knees before the Father,
verses.comment: Kneeling in prayer shows reverence and humility. Paul’s posture indicates deep intercession for the church.

verses.text: from whom every family in heaven and on earth is named,
verses.comment: All spiritual and earthly families derive their existence and identity from the Father. This points to the unity and universality of the family of God.

verses.text: that according to the riches of his glory he may grant you to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in your inner being,
verses.comment: Strength from the Spirit in the inner self leads to spiritual transformation, anticipated in the new covenant promises (see Ezek. 36:26-27).

verses.text: so that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith—being rooted and grounded in love,
verses.comment: Christ’s indwelling is transformative, possible through faith and lived out in love—echoing Christ’s own teaching (John 14:23).

verses.text: that you may have strength to comprehend with all the saints what is the width and length and height and depth,
verses.comment: Only in unity with all believers can one begin to grasp the immeasurable dimensions of Christ’s love, suggesting the importance of the whole church in deepening faith.

verses.text: and to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge, so that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.
verses.comment: Being filled with God’s fullness is the ultimate goal of Christian life—a process completed in the corporate body of believers, growing together into holiness.

verses.text: Now to him who is able to do far more abundantly than all that we ask or think, according to the power at work within us,
verses.comment: God’s power surpasses human limits and expectations. His work is beyond comprehension, performed within us as the believing community.

verses.text: to him be glory in the church and in Christ Jesus throughout all generations, forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: Glory is to God through the church and Christ Jesus, eternally. This underscores God’s purpose for a visibly united, worshiping, Christ-centered people across all history.
